nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor will improve economic outcomes such as productivity, cognition, well-being, and earnings

Context: Low-income urban adults in Chennai face environmental and psychosocial barriers (heat, noise, crowding, distress) that may impair sleep and its role as an input to productivity and well-being

Method: We conducted a randomized controlled trial (N=452) in Chennai using continuous actigraphy, a month-long paid data-entry job to measure productivity and labor supply, and cross-randomized night-sleep interventions with a nap intervention

Evidence (baseline): Actigraphy shows participants slept on average 5.5 hours/night, spent ~8 hours in bed, had ~31 awakenings/night and sleep efficiency ~70%, similar to clinical populations with sleep disorders

Result (night treatments on sleep): Nighttime interventions (devices + encouragement or devices + incentives) increased night sleep by 27 minutes/night on average by inducing more time in bed (≈38 minutes), without improving sleep efficiency

Result (nap treatment on sleep): The workplace nap treatment led participants to sleep during the nap period in ≈93% of sessions and increased daytime sleep by about 14 minutes/day (with higher nap sleep quality in office)

Method detail: Work measurement design—active typing time, piece-rate randomized incentives, output and earnings recorded; cognitive, well-being, and preference measures collected through incentivized tasks and surveys

Result (effects of night sleep on outcomes): Increased nighttime sleep had no detectable positive effects on overall index, cognition, productivity, decision making, well-being, or preferences and caused small decreases in labor supply and (marginal) earnings

Result (effects of naps on outcomes): Afternoon workplace naps increased the overall summary index by 0.12 standard deviations and produced significant improvements in productivity, psychological well-being, and cognition, while reducing work time

Claim: Naps and increased night sleep are not equivalent in this setting—per-minute benefits of naps exceed those of nighttime sleep for many outcomes, and naps occur in a higher-quality environment and different circadian timing
Claim (expert priors vs evidence): Surveys of 119 experts predicted sizable economic gains from increasing night sleep (e.g., 7% increase in output) but the RCT strongly rejects these predictions

Assumption / possible explanations: The lack of benefits from increased night sleep may reflect (a) low sleep quality/efficiency in the population limiting marginal returns, and/or (b) lab-induced severe deprivation findings not generalizing to modest, field-relevant increases

Conclusion: Policies that increase time in bed may raise sleep duration but can carry opportunity costs (reduced work time) and may not yield expected economic benefits unless sleep quality is improved or context differs

Policy implication / claim: Naps in comfortable workplaces may be an effective, low-cost intervention to improve productivity, cognition, and well-being in similar settings and merit consideration by employers and policymakers

Limitation: Results are short-run (three-week treatments) in a specific data-entry job and urban Chennai; external validity and long-term health effects of changed sleep require further field studies and interventions that improve sleep efficiency
